column1: Adoption is seen as a high priority service in Tameside and is an integral part of care planning for children.

Such an approach predates the high profile given to Adoption recently by both the Government and the media and is reflected by the interest of other Local Authorities and Government Departments in what have been identified as areas of good practice initiated by Tameside. These were highlighted in the Social Services inspectorate publication "Adopting Changes" (December 2000 DoH) and also as a result of the joint SSI/Audit Commission inspection into Children's Services in 2002.

Tameside's Adoption Service is provided by one team of social workers who are experienced and skilled in children and families social work as well as adoption. This enables a sharing of ideas and a unity of purpose, which benefits all involved in the adoption process. In many Authorities there is a split between the tasks of recruiting and assessing adopters and the placing of children for adoption.
Adoption is about meeting the needs of children not meeting the needs of adults who wish to adopt.

Over the past two years we have seen the introduction of much new legislation to govern Adoption Practice. We now have National Minimum Standards for Adoption as well as the Adoption and Children Act 2002. There is procedural guidance for the provision of Post Adoption Support and for Inter Country Adoption.

Adoption has changed markedly over the past 30 years. In 1977 20,000 children were placed for Adoption. The majority of these were babies. Thirty years later as society's views and attitudes have changed this figure has decreased greatly. In 1999 2,200 children were placed for adoption. Over the past six years however, this figure has grown due to greater acknowledgement of the role adoption can play in making permanent plans for children. Although the number of children adopted has dropped in the past 30 years the number of children adopted from care has grown.

The majority of children placed for Adoption will have been removed from their parents through the court system due to maltreatment or risk of harm in one form or another. All of these children will have had their plan for adoption approved by the court.

These children come to adoption with their own identity, background and family history, all of which will impact on their adoptive home and require understanding and acceptance in order to increase the possibility of a successful placement.
Of the children placed for Adoption by Tameside in 2005/06, one baby was placed at the request of parents.
• 8 were girls and 9 were boys.
• 10 children were under 2 years old.
• 4 children were over 5 years old.
• 1 child is of black or of mixed race.
• 8 children with uncertain developmental futures.

Children who come into care are in most cases initially placed in foster care. Great efforts are made to keep siblings together. The Authority was praised for its siblings placement policy in the Social Services Inspectorate publication 'Adopting Changes'.

Children awaiting adoption need careful preparation and explanation about what is going to happen to them and why. Tameside has a specialist worker to do this direct work with children. It will include preparing a Life Story Book for a child to take with them into adoption. This will contain information vital to the child about his family and identity. Some birth parents feel able to help in this process to help their children move on to another family.

Most children will need to maintain some level of contact with their birth parents in order to promote their self-esteem and identity. In most cases this is achieved through indirect letterbox contact, although for some children direct contact with significant family members will be an identified need. Tameside wishes to recruit adopters who will value and promote a child's identity and history and who will be positive about openness in adoption.
• Prospective adopters must be 21 years. There is no upper age limit.
• Single adopters, or one of a couple must be domiciled in the British Isles or the adopters must be habitually resident for one year in the British Isles. ( UK , Channel Islands and Isle of Man ).
• Unmarried and non-civil registered couples can adopt jointly.
• Birth parents partner - married or civil registered, can adopt without birth parent having to adopt.
• Where one of an unmarried couple has adopted under the 1976 Adoption Act, his or her partner can adopt alone and the adopter need not adopt again.

• Married Stepfathers/mothers and registered civil partners can acquire PR by agreement with all parents with Parental Responsibility or by court order - Parental Responsibility is therefore shared. This is an alternative to step-parent adoption.
• Applications are welcomed from single people.
• Tameside welcomes applications from same sex couples.

• Tameside offers a service to all Tameside residents and also welcomes applications from those living outside the borough, particularly from people wishing to adopt older children, sibling groups or children with special needs.

• All applicants undergo statutory checks carried out through the police, Services to Children and Young People, health, education and probation services. Anyone with an offence against children is barred by law from becoming an adopter. Personal references e.g. from friends or employers are also taken up.
• All prospective adopters undergo a medical examination carried out by their own GP.

• Prospective adopters are viewed by the Local Authority as very important as a result great care is taken in the training, assessment and support of all applicants. Preparation for adoption groups is held before assessment. These last 3½ days.
• Interest is particularly welcomed from people who can offer a home to:-
• People who have already parented and have older children.
• Children of black or mixed race.

• Tameside also accepts applications from people wishing to adopt from overseas. Such assessments are carried out by a voluntary adoption agency and the costs, are around £4,000 this is met by the adopters.
• Anyone contacting the department will be able to talk to a social worker experienced in Adoption practice. An information pack is available and will be sent to anyone who wants to know more.
Children Waiting to be Placed for Adoption
View a list of children that are waiting to be adopted.
Each child is the subject of a Care Order made by a court. The Authority has had to present a Care Plan to the court outlining and timetabling its plan to place the child for Adoption.
Due to the size of the Authority, Tameside's children are rarely placed within the borough.

Detailed and informative profiles of the children are prepared and sent to other Local Authorities and Voluntary Adoption Agencies, many throughout the North West. For some children it is necessary for a national search, which includes advertisements in specialist magazines and referral to the National Adoption Register.

Tameside is a member of the Greater Manchester Consortia who are now partners in an agreement between Cumbria and Lancashire County Councils, Greater Merseyside and Manchester and Salford Consortia comprising a total of 22 Local Authorities.
The Local Authorities have agreed to work together in collaboration to develop a regional adoption resource.
One of the aims is to improve and promote effective matching of children requiring adoption and to increase the availability of high quality adoptive parents.

Tameside is one of very few Local Authorities to carry out Life Appreciation Days for its children. Pioneered by Barnardos New Families in the North East, such days consist of as many people as possible who have had an involvement with a child, talking about their experiences and memories and helping to bring the child to life for the prospective Adopters. This practice has been praised and copied in many areas and is now a regular occurrence in Tameside.

The value of post adoption support has been recognised more in recent years as being crucial to the success of adoptive placements. A child's need for explanation and knowledge about his background may grow as he gets older. His behaviour may increasingly reflect the impact of poor or abusive parenting in his early years.

Tameside Adoption Team aims to provide a comprehensive adoption support/ advice service to all persons affected by adoption and resident in Tameside. The service offered is based on statutory requirements, sound principles and a model of good practice.

• The Local Authority has a responsibility to birth parents of children placed for adoption and will arrange for independent support and counselling from the point that a decision is made that their child should be placed for adoption.
• The Local Authority operates a post adoption Letterbox service to facilitate the exchange of photographs and letters between adopters and birth family members. This will be reviewed annually.

• Where the adoption plan recommends that direct contact with birth family members is in the child's best interest the Local Authority provides a support service to the child, birth family and adoptive family in order to facilitate, monitor and review contact to ensure that contact meets the child's needs.

• As part of the service provision the Local Authority Adoption Services operates a Post Adoption Surgery, this provides an opportunity for any Tameside resident affected by adoption the opportunity to meet with the Adoption Support Co-ordinator in order to access counselling, advice and information.
• Children who may be adopted, their parents and guardians.
• Adopted persons, their parents, birth parents and former guardians.
• Children of adoptive parents (whether or not adopted).
• Children who are natural siblings of an adopted child.
• Related persons in relation to adoptive children.

An appointment can be made by telephone on 0161 342 4162, the Adoption Clerk will arrange a convenient date and time for you. The surgeries operate every Thursday from 9.30am - 1.00pm and are held at Services to Children and Young People's Offices, 56 Warrington Street, Ashton-under-Lyne.

The aim of the post adoption surgery is to offer advice and to enable those affected by adoption to either access existing services or to be offered advice with regards to access to specialist services for those eligible.
Tameside Adoption Team provides support groups for adopters, these are held every six weeks. The purpose of these meetings is to offer support and enable adopters to share experiences.
The meetings will sometimes include speakers as requested by group members.
The groups take place at a venue in Droylsden and the dates and times are as follows:
• 21st February 2007 - Subject for Discussion - Story Work
• 4th April 2007 - Subject for Discussion - "Managing attachment issues in respect of children who are adopted"
• 16th May 2007 - "Understanding and managing challenging behavious in children"
• 27th June 2007 - Subject for Discussion - "Education and the Adopted Child"
• 8th August 2007 - Drop in Coffe session, discussion of planning activities for the summer break, information will be available in relation to local playschemes
• 19th September 2007 - "Discussion session relating to Life Story Work"
• 24th October 2007 - Coffee and Drop-in session
• 28th November 2007 - Education and the Adopted Child, "How to prepare your child for school"
• 5th December 2007 - Coffee and Drop-in session, discussion relating to feedback from the years discussions and activities and plan fuiture groups for 2008.
• 20th December 2007 - Christmas Party, venue to be confirmed
A summer event will also be organised for adoptive families, details will be available at the beginning of May.
If you are an adoptive parent and would like to attend the group you can complete the confirmation slip or alternatively you can contact the Adoption Support Co-ordinator on 0161 342 4162.

We are committed to the continual development of our service and are planning to expand support service. In the coming year we will consult with birth parents and former guardians of adopted children with a view to establishing support groups.

If you are a birth parent, grandparent, former guardian of an adopted child and would be interested in attending or assisting in the setting up of a support group in Tameside, please contact the Adoption Team on 0161 342 4162. We would be very pleased to hear from you.
For further information relating to adoption support services within Tameside, please telephone 0161 342 4162 and ask to speak to the Adoption Support Co ordinator.
If you would like further information about adoption please complete the referral form or, write to:
